meta.title: How Emotionally Intelligent Is Your Child?
meta.description: A research-backed assessment of your child's emotional awareness, self-regulation, empathy, and frustration tolerance. Based on frameworks from Gottman, Yale RULER, and CASEL.
meta.intro:
Emotional intelligence isn't something kids are born with — it's built through thousands of small moments where feelings are named, validated, and worked through. This quiz helps you see where your child is now in understanding and managing their emotional world.

Answer based on what your child does consistently, not on their best day.

sources.name: John Gottman — Raising An Emotionally Intelligent Child

questions.text: When your child is upset, how do they describe what they're feeling?
questions.subtext: Listen for the words they actually use, not the words you wish they'd use.
questions.source: Gottman — emotion naming as foundation of emotional intelligence

options.text: Uses specific words like 'frustrated,' 'disappointed,' 'nervous,' or 'left out'
Uses basic words like 'mad,' 'sad,' or 'happy' but can't be more specific
Doesn't use feeling words — mostly cries, yells, or shuts down

questions.text: Does your child notice and comment on other people's emotions?
questions.subtext: Like saying 'Dad seems grumpy' or 'That kid looks scared.'
questions.source: Yale RULER — recognizing emotions in others

options.text: Often notices and names what others seem to be feeling
Sometimes notices but needs prompting to put it into words
Doesn't seem to notice or mention others' emotional states

questions.text: Can your child tell you why they're upset, not just that they're upset?
questions.subtext: 'I'm mad because she took my turn' vs. just 'I'm mad!'

options.text: Can usually explain what triggered the feeling
Can explain sometimes, with help from you
Can't explain — just knows they feel bad

questions.text: When your child gets really angry, what happens?
questions.source: Gottman — regulation capacity under emotional stress

options.text: They're angry but can take a break, use words, or calm down with minimal support
Big reaction at first (yelling, throwing), but recovers within 5-10 minutes with help
Escalates quickly and stays dysregulated for 20+ minutes

questions.text: How does your child handle waiting for something they really want?
questions.subtext: Waiting for their turn, waiting for a treat, waiting to open a present.
questions.source: Yale RULER — impulse control and delayed gratification

options.text: Can wait without constant reminders or meltdowns
Waits but needs distraction, encouragement, or frequent check-ins
Cannot wait without a full breakdown

questions.text: Can your child stop themselves mid-action when you give a boundary?
questions.subtext: Like you say 'don't touch that' and they pull their hand back, even if they're annoyed.

options.text: Yes, they stop even if they don't like it
Sometimes stops, sometimes tests the boundary
Rarely stops — usually has to be physically redirected

questions.text: What does your child do when they see another child crying or hurt?
questions.subtext: At the park, in their class, a sibling — watch their instinct.
questions.source: Gottman — empathic response as emotional intelligence marker

options.text: Shows concern — asks what's wrong, offers comfort, gets an adult
Notices but doesn't know what to do, or needs prompting to respond
Doesn't seem to notice or care, or gets upset themselves

questions.text: Can your child imagine how someone else might feel in a situation?
questions.subtext: 'How do you think she felt when that happened?' Can they guess?

options.text: Can take a guess, even if it's not always accurate
Needs coaching but can eventually get there
Can't imagine others' perspectives — everything is about their own experience

questions.text: How does your child react when something doesn't work the way they expected?
questions.subtext: A puzzle piece won't fit, a block tower falls, a drawing doesn't look 'right.'

options.text: Gets frustrated but keeps trying or asks for help
Gets upset and gives up, but can be encouraged back
Immediate rage-quit — throws it, screams, refuses to try again

questions.text: When your child loses a game or doesn't get picked first, what happens?
questions.subtext: Board games, relay races, being chosen for a team — how do they handle not winning?
questions.source: Gottman — emotional resilience in competitive contexts

options.text: Disappointed but recovers quickly, can say 'good game' or try again
Very upset but calms down with reassurance within a few minutes
Melts down, accuses others of cheating, refuses to play again

high.headline: Rich emotional vocabulary
high.detail: Your child can name what they're feeling with specificity, notice emotions in others, and explain what's causing their feelings. This vocabulary is the foundation of emotional intelligence — you can't manage what you can't name.
high.strength: Strong emotion vocabulary — your child has the language tools to understand and express their inner world

medium.headline: Emotion words are growing
medium.detail: Your child is building their feelings vocabulary but still relies on basic words like 'mad' or 'sad.' This is developmentally normal — emotion language grows through hearing adults name feelings out loud in real situations. Your narration teaches them.
medium.concern: Emotion vocabulary is still developing — narrating your own feelings ('I feel frustrated when the line is this long') helps your child build theirs

low.headline: Emotions are felt, not yet named
low.detail: Your child experiences big feelings but doesn't have the words to describe them yet. This makes everything harder — they know something feels bad, but they can't tell you what or why. Building this vocabulary is one of the most powerful things you can do.
low.concern: Emotion vocabulary is just beginning to emerge. Naming your child's feelings for them ('You seem disappointed') plants the seeds for their own emotional awareness.

high.headline: Can ride the wave of big feelings
high.detail: Your child doesn't need to be calm all the time — they get upset. But they can recover, wait when needed, and stop themselves even when it's hard. This self-regulation capacity is what lets emotional intelligence show up in real life.
high.strength: Strong self-regulation — your child can manage impulses and calm themselves down with minimal support

medium.headline: Regulation is a work in progress
medium.detail: Your child can regulate sometimes, especially with your help, but still gets overwhelmed easily. This skill develops slowly — the brain circuitry for self-control isn't fully built until the mid-20s. What matters now is learning to recover, not learning to never lose it.
medium.concern: Self-regulation is developing — staying close during meltdowns and co-regulating ('I'm here, let's breathe together') teaches the skill over time

low.headline: Big emotions, little control
low.detail: Your child goes from zero to meltdown fast and stays there for a long time. They can't wait, can't stop themselves, and can't calm down without significant adult support. This isn't defiance — it's a developmental skill they haven't built yet.
low.concern: Self-regulation is still emerging. If intense dysregulation is constant and interfering with daily life, talk to your pediatrician about whether extra support would help.

high.headline: Naturally tuned in to others
high.detail: Your child notices when someone is hurting and wants to help. They can imagine how others might feel, even if they don't always get it right. This empathy makes emotional connection possible — it's how relationships are built.
high.strength: Strong empathy — your child can read emotional cues and respond with care

medium.headline: Empathy is emerging
medium.detail: Your child is starting to notice others' feelings but doesn't always know what to do with that awareness. Empathy develops through experience — the more you narrate emotions in others ('Look, he's crying — I think he's sad his mom left'), the more your child learns to see it.
medium.concern: Empathy is building — pointing out others' emotions and modeling compassionate responses helps this skill grow

low.headline: Still figuring out the 'other'
low.detail: Your child doesn't yet seem tuned in to how others feel. This can be developmental — younger children are naturally egocentric. It can also be sensory or wiring-related. If lack of empathy is paired with other social struggles, mention it to your pediatrician.
low.concern: Empathy hasn't emerged yet. For most children, this skill grows through direct teaching and modeling. If it persists beyond age 5-6, discuss with your pediatrician.

high.headline: Resilient when things go wrong
high.detail: Your child can handle disappointment, failure, and losing without falling apart. They might be upset, but they recover and try again. This frustration tolerance is what makes learning possible — every new skill requires failing first.
high.strength: Strong frustration tolerance — your child can handle setbacks and keep going

medium.headline: Frustration tolerance is building
medium.detail: Your child struggles with things going wrong but can be coached through it. This skill strengthens when adults stay calm and empathetic during the meltdown instead of fixing or dismissing. Your steady presence teaches resilience.
medium.concern: Frustration tolerance is developing — staying present during disappointment ('I know, it's so hard when it doesn't work') helps build this skill

low.headline: Low tolerance for things going wrong
low.detail: Your child cannot handle frustration — losing, failing, or things not going as planned triggers immediate, intense meltdowns. This can be temperamental, developmental, or a sign of underlying anxiety. Either way, it's teachable — but it takes time and patience.
low.concern: Frustration tolerance is low. This is one of the hardest EQ skills to build. If it's interfering with learning, playing, or friendships, talk to your pediatrarian about whether support would help.

ready.headline: Emotionally Intelligent & Growing
ready.subheadline: Your child has a strong emotional foundation.
ready.explanation: Your child is showing the core competencies of emotional intelligence: they can name feelings, manage their reactions, notice others' emotions, and handle disappointment. These aren't static traits — they'll keep developing — but the foundation is solid.
nextSteps: Keep narrating emotions in everyday moments — yours, theirs, characters in books. The vocabulary keeps expanding.
Let them struggle sometimes. Jumping in to fix frustration robs them of the chance to build tolerance.
Name the emotional intelligence you see: 'You stayed calm even though you were upset — that's hard.'
Model imperfection. Let them see you frustrated, then see you recover. That's the most powerful teaching.
ready.watchOutFor: Emotional intelligence doesn't mean your child won't have meltdowns. It means they recover faster and learn from them. Expect regression during stress, transitions, or developmental leaps — that's normal.
ready.encouragement: You've built something powerful. Emotional intelligence is the single best predictor of lifelong wellbeing — better than IQ, better than academic achievement. This is the work that matters.
ready.comparativeContext: Children who score in this range are well-equipped to navigate friendships, handle school stress, and build healthy relationships.
ready.retakeAdvice: No need to retake — your child is showing strong emotional competence

almost.headline: Emotional Skills Are Building
almost.subheadline: Your child is developing emotional awareness — some areas are stronger than others.
almost.explanation: Your child has some emotional tools but is still building others. This is the most common result. Emotional intelligence isn't innate — it's taught, practiced, and strengthened over years. Look at the domain breakdown below to see where focused support could help.
nextSteps: Focus on the 'Room to Grow' domains below — small daily practice in those areas accelerates development
Read books about feelings together — stories are safe ways to practice emotional concepts
Validate feelings before solving problems: 'You're so mad right now' before 'let's figure this out'
Give them the words: 'That feeling is called jealousy' or 'I think you're feeling left out'
almost.watchOutFor: Don't expect emotional intelligence to look like adult-level self-control. Your child is allowed to have big feelings and big reactions. The goal isn't suppression — it's awareness and recovery.
almost.encouragement: Emotional intelligence is built in the thousands of small moments where feelings are named, validated, and worked through. You're doing that work every day, even when it doesn't feel like progress. It is.
almost.comparativeContext: Most children in this range develop stronger emotional skills through consistent emotional coaching from adults. Progress happens faster than you'd think.
almost.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 3-4 months to track progress

not-yet.headline: Emotional Tools Are Still Emerging
not-yet.subheadline: Your child is building emotional awareness from the ground up — and that's okay.
not-yet.explanation: Your child doesn't yet have the vocabulary, regulation, empathy, or frustration tolerance that emotional intelligence requires. This isn't a character flaw — it's a developmental gap. Some children build these skills early, some need more time and teaching. What matters is starting where you are.
nextSteps: Talk to your pediatrician about what you're seeing — especially if meltdowns are constant, intense, and interfering with daily life
Start small: pick one emotion and name it consistently for a week. 'You seem frustrated.' That's it. Repeat.
Stay close during meltdowns. Your calm presence is teaching regulation, even when it doesn't feel like it.
Consider whether your child has had opportunities to practice — group settings, peer conflict, waiting, losing. If not, create them.
not-yet.watchOutFor: If emotional dysregulation is paired with other developmental concerns (speech delays, sensory issues, social struggles), bring it up with your pediatrician. Early intervention makes a huge difference.
not-yet.encouragement: Emotional intelligence is one of the most teachable skills in childhood. Your child isn't behind — they're at the beginning. And you're asking the right questions, which means you're already doing the work.
not-yet.comparativeContext: Children who score in this range often benefit from explicit emotional coaching, books about feelings, and practice in structured group settings. Growth happens with consistent support.
not-yet.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 2-3 months to track progress
